par.text: Gallium is a silvery-white metal with a bluish tinge. At room temperature it is soft enough to be cut with a knife, but at low temperatures gallium is hard and brittle. Gallium is rather inert at room temperature, but when heated it reacts with oxygen, selenium and chlorine. The existence of gallium was predicted by Dmitri Mendeleyev, but it was discovered and obtained in 1875 by the French chemist Paul Emil
